title-group.article-title: Predictive value of obesity-related indices for incident type 2 diabetes mellitus: a longitudinal study of the Fukushima Health Database 2015–2021

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Obesity indices that combine anthropometric and lipid measurements, such as the atherogenic index of plasma (AIP), cardiometabolic index (CMI), lipid accumulation product (LAP), metabolic score for insulin resistance (Mets-IR), triglyceride-glucose (TyG) index, and visceral adiposity index (VAI), have been recommended as surrogates for assessing cardiometabolic risk. This study aimed to examine the association between these indices and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) incidence risk using large routine health checkup data.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This retrospective cohort study involved 195,989 participants aged 35–74 years who attended the Specific Health Checkups in 2015 and were observed until 2021 in Fukushima, Japan. We used multivariable Cox regression analysis to examine the associations between the indices and T2DM risk and evaluated the diagnostic utility of the indices.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The accumulated T2DM incidence rate per 100,000 person-years over a mean follow-up of 4.61 years was 706.6 in males and 441.2 in females. Multiple adjusted hazard ratios were significantly higher in the highest quartile of indices (1.33–4.22 fold higher) compared to the lowest quartile. The increased risk in the higher quartiles was more pronounced in participants aged < 50 years than in those aged ≥ 50 years for both sexes. The areas under the receiver operating characteristic curves (AUC) of AIP, CMI, LAP, and VAI were between 0.821 and 0.844, whereas those of Mets-IR and TyG were between 0.756 and 0.780. For both sexes, AUCs for AIP, CMI, and LAP showed no significant differences (P values > 0.05), but other pairwise indices had significant differences (P values < 0.001). AUCs were higher in participants with a body mass index (BMI) of < 25 kg/m2 or aged < 50 years than in those with a BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2 or aged ≥ 50 years, respectively. Net reclassification improvements of models for CMI and LAP were similar to AIP, while those for Mets-IR, TyG, and VAI were significantly lower than AIP.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Obesity indices are positively associated with and applicable for predicting new-onset T2DM in Japanese adults, particularly AIP, CMI, and LAP.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s13098-025-01795-5.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), a multifaceted and interrelated disease, is characterized by insulin resistance and is causally associated with weight gain and hyperglycemia [1]. To prevent T2DM, lifestyle interventions may be more effective than drug treatments [2], in which achieving and maintaining optimal body weight is essential [3].

Body mass index (BMI) is a common measurement parameter for general obesity, while waist circumference (WC), waist-to-height ratio, and waist-to-hip ratio are better than BMI in characterizing central or abdominal obesity [4]. Elevated fasting glucose levels indicate impaired glucose regulation and may serve as an early indicator of insulin resistance and diabetes onset [5]; however, its efficacy compared to other indices for detecting diabetes needs to be validated [6]. Blood-based single lipid measurements of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), total lipoprotein cholesterol, and triglyceride (TG) vary in their ability to predict T2DM risk.

Body fat is more accurately measured by computer tomography, dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry, and bioelectrical impedance analysis for visceral adipose tissue [7–9] or body fat percentage [10–12]; however, these methods are inconvenient and expensive. Several novel nontraditional anthropometric indices and lipid parameters have been recommended as cost-effective surrogate markers of visceral fat measurements, such as obesity-related atherogenic index of plasma (AIP) [13, 14], cardiometabolic index (CMI) [15], lipid accumulation product (LAP) [3, 14–22], the metabolic score for insulin resistance (Mets-IR) [14, 23], triglyceride-glucose (TyG) index [3, 14, 16, 20, 21, 24–26], and body fat distribution related visceral adiposity index (VAI) [3, 14, 15, 18, 20–22]. These cross-sectional and cohort studies have reported optimal results on the associations between markers and the risk of metabolic syndrome or T2DM. Studies in this area have been conducted in the Japanese general population, including an early study of LAP in young workers [27], and more recent retrospective cohort studies on LAP [28], Mets-IR [29], and TyG [30, 31].

In 2008, the Japanese government issued a health policy that included detailed annual health checkups and specific counselling (health promotion guidance) for all beneficiaries, targeting individuals at risk of metabolic syndrome [32]. The annual basic health checkup incorporates routine clinically measured anthropometric and lipid parameters that may identify T2DM at an early stage. This study addressed gaps in obesity-related indices from Japanese insurance data. It examined their associations with T2DM incidence and predictive capability using health checkup data, informing T2DM prediction tools.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: The Fukushima Health Database (FDB) includes data from annual health checkups and health insurance claims of the National Health Insurance, part of the Employee Health Insurance (the Kyoukai Kenpo) for employees of small-to-medium-sized enterprises, and other insurances. Health insurance coverage in Fukushima Prefecture in 2015 was > 70% [33].

This study extracted data from 313,623 residents aged 35–74 years who attended health checkups in 2015 (Fig. 1). According to the 2015 prefecture census and a 48.2% health checkup implementation rate among individuals aged 40–74 years in 2016 [33], the study participants accounted for > 66% of the Fukushima population aged 35–74 years who attend annual health checkups. After excluding patients with diagnosed T2DM, using insulin or oral medication for control of T2DM, a history of stroke, heart disease, or renal disease reported in 2015, as well as those who did not attend health checkups or whose claims data for 2016 and 2021 were unavailable, 195,989 participants were included in the analysis.Fig. 1
Data flow for analysis, the Fukushima Health Database 2015–2021

The study was approved by the Fukushima Medical University Ethical Review Committee (Generic 2021–169). The study was conducted using secondary administrative data accumulated in the database, with personal information anonymised. Thus, informed consent was not obtained from participants.

sec.title: Demographic and lifestyle factors
sec.p: Demographic data included age and sex. The self-administered questionnaires included questions on medical history, alcohol consumption, smoking status, physical activity, and dietary habits and behavior.

sec.title: Clinical examinations
Confirmation of T2DM morbidity
sec.p: For the diagnosis of diabetes, one blood glucose test is mandatory by the Japanese clinical practice guideline [34]. In this study, information on the occurrence of T2DM, including medical and diagnostic procedure combinations and dispensing receipts [35], was identified from the database from 2016 to 2021. We reviewed inpatient and outpatient receipts identified based on the International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision (ICD-10 code) E11-E14 and pharmaceutical classification 396 (antidiabetic agent) for T2DM.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: We employed five age- and sex-specific multiple imputations under the missing-at-random assumption to address missing values in lifestyle variables and clinical measurements to minimise the potential for inference bias, such as blood pressure and cholesterol, using the fcs method. The maximum missing data was 8.1%, observed in variables including smoking among females and hyperlipidemia or hypertension drug therapy in both sexes. Detailed information on the number of missing variables is shown in Additional file 3: Table S1. All study results we reported are combined results for imputed datasets.

Descriptive characteristics were presented as means ± SE or median ± IQR for continuous variables and numbers (percentages) for dichotomous variables. A one-way non-parametric test for continuous variables and a chi-square test for categorical variables were used to compare the general characteristics between males and females.

In the preliminary analysis, we observed significant interactions between sex and each index in relation to T2DM risk. Hereafter, we used the sex-specific Cox regression model to estimate the association between obesity indices and T2DM incidence risk in the follow-up period between 2016 and 2021. Person-years were calculated based on the onset date of outpatient or inpatient care (the date on which they were admitted to the hospital or took drugs initially), whichever came first. If there were no recorded death dates, the last health checkup date was recorded as censored. Hazard ratios (HR) and 95% confidence intervals (95% CI) were estimated using the first quartile of indices as the reference. Multivariable regression analyses were conducted with adjustments for variables based on previous publications on cardiovascular risk factors identified in studies involving Fukushima residents [36–39]. Collinearity among the indices was checked by using the variance inflation factor (VIF) method before running the regression analyses. Only minor collinearity was found for BMI (VIF = 4.66) and WC (VIF = 4.69) in all covariates in men. Model 1 was adjusted for age, smoking status, alcohol consumption frequency, FPG, SBP, DBP, and use of hypertension or hyperlipidemia drug therapy. Model 2 further included BMI and WC measurements. Model 3 further included the HDL-C (logarithm) and LDL-C (logarithm). In each model, covariates already included in the index formula were excluded from the adjustment [40]. BMI, WC, SBP, and DBP were normally distributed. Obesity indices were categorized into quartiles (Q1–Q4), and a linear trend was evaluated using the median value of lipid indices in the quartile categories as continuous variables. Given the complex role overweight/obesity plays in T2DM development, we assessed the potential interactions between indices and BMI and provided a stratified analysis using a BMI cut-off of 25 kg/m2. To further explore age effects, we conducted a stratified analysis for participants aged < 50 years and those aged ≥ 50 years for T2DM risk.

To examine the dose–response associations between obesity indices and T2DM risk, we presented restricted cubic spline (RCS) curves with knots at the 5th, 35th, 65th, and 95th percentiles, using the second knot as the reference, for AIP, TyG, and log-transformed CMI, LAP, Mets-IR, and VAI.

Logistic regression models were used to examine the diagnostic utility of the obesity indices based on the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC). Logarithmic transformation was performed for LAP, CMI, Mets-IR, and VAI. The cutoff values for the obesity indices were estimated based on the Youden index and antilogarithmic transformation was subsequently performed for CMI, LAP, Mets-IR, and VAI. Using the model for AIP as the reference, integrated discrimination improvement (IDI) and net reclassification improvement (NRI) were used to estimate the predictive performance for models of obesity indices.

To address the association of obesity indices with T2DM cases diagnosed later in the follow-up period, we conducted a sensitivity analysis excluding participants diagnosed with T2DM within the first 2 years of follow-up or those taking hypertension or hyperlipidemia therapy drugs. Additionally, regression analyses were performed using the complete case analysis (no imputations) to confirm the study findings. All analyses were conducted separately for males and females to account for lifestyle disparities using SAS version 9.4, for Windows (SAS Institute, Cary, NC). All reported P values were two-sided, and P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Table 1 shows the characteristics of the participants during specific health checkups in 2015. The mean age was 55.2 and 57.8 years for males and females, respectively. Current smoking rates were 40.3% and 10.9%, and daily alcohol consumption were 45.9% and 11.9% in males and females, respectively. Females had higher LDL-C and HDL-C levels and hyperlipidemia drug therapy but lower hypertension drug therapy use compared to males. Other clinical measurements and obesity indices were higher in males than in females.Table 1

Over a mean follow-up duration of 4.61 years, the number (person-years) of new T2DM cases was 3,057 (432,622.3) in males and 2,078 (471,013.0) in females. Thus, the cumulative T2DM incidence rate was 706.6 and 441.2 per 100,000 person-years in males and females, respectively.

Higher obesity index scores were significantly associated with T2DM incidence risk during the follow-up period in multiple adjusted models, with a significant increase in linear trends (Table 2). The associations were more prominent in females than in males and relatively stronger in Mets-IR, TyG, and VAI than in AIP, CMI, and LAP in both males and females.Table 2

In each model, the adjustment excluded those that had already been included in the index formula

After excluding participants diagnosed with T2DM in the first 2 years of follow-up or those using hypertension or hyperlipidemia drug therapy, significant positive associations between the indices and T2DM risk remained in both males and females. The magnitudes of the associations were similar between the two sensitivity analyses for each index (Additional file 3: Table S1). Similar significant associations between the indices and T2DM risk were shown by repeated the complete case analysis (without imputations) (Additional file 3: Table S2).

In addition, in further stratified analysis, few participants with BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2 in the Q1 and Q2 groups of Mets-IR, only HR and 95% CI of Q4 vs. Q3 were shown. In participants who were overweight/obese significant positive associations between the indices and T2DM incidence risk, except for LAP, were observed (Table 3). The increased risk of T2DM incidence in higher quartiles versus the lowest quartile for each index was more pronounced in participants aged < 50 years than in those aged ≥ 50 years in both sexes (Table 4).Table 3

The AUCs of the obesity indices for the identification of new T2DM cases were higher in females than in males. AUCs were 0.821–0.844 for AIP, CMI, LAP, and VAI nd 0.756–0.780 for Mets-IR and TyG (Fig. 2 and Table 5). Both men and women, except for an insignificant difference in AUCs among indices of AIP, CMI, and LAP (P values > 0.05), showed significant differences in AUCs among other pairwise indices (P values < 0.001). Overall, men and women with a BMI < 25 kg/m2 or aged < 50 years demonstrated higher AUCs for T2DM risk models than those with a BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2 or aged ≥ 50 years. The difference in the discriminant ability of indices by age groups was more pronounced in men (Additional file 3: Table S4).Fig. 2

Compared to the AIP model, a significantly lower IDI was observed for other indices, with the exception of CMI in females. Similar to the differences among AUCs, a significantly lower NRI was observed for Mets-IR, TyG, and VAI, and similar to CMI and LAP compared to AIP. The cut-off of the diagnostic value corresponding to the Youden index was similar for TyG and VAI in both sexes and relatively higher for AIP, CMI, LAP, and Mets-IR in males than in females.

Dose–response relationships for T2DM risk (Additional file 1: Fig. S1A and Additional file 2: Fig S1B), consistent with Cox regression, showed significant associations after the second knot for all indices, notably logMets-IR (both sexes) and TyG (women); nonlinear associations were significant for all indices in men, but only logCMI, logMets-IR, and TyG in women.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Obesity indices are comprehensive measurements that show strong positive associations with T2DM incidence risk. The AIP, CMI, and LAP indices showed better diagnostic and predictive performances than Mets-IR, TyG, and VAI in both sexes.

Diabetes remains a significant public health challenge in Japan. In addition to FPG, hemoglobin A1c and anthropometric measurements, diabetes screening tools with more context-specific and objective for early T2DM diagnosis are needed [6]. To our knowledge, this is the first study to compare obesity surrogate markers associated with T2DM risk based on insurance information, including the initial AIP estimation, in a large Japanese population. This study adds evidence on the use of combined lipid profiles in identifying the T2DM incidence risk by utilizing a health insurance database. Furthermore, evaluating the diagnostic and predictive capabilities of these indices may provide insights for developing simple prediction tools, including the cut-off values for risk assessment.

Excess fat accumulation contributes to T2DM development, particularly abdominal or central adiposity, in Asian populations, and T2DM onset occurs at a relatively young age and with a low BMI [41]. Insulin resistance (IR) is a lack of physiological response to insulin, which acts on peripheral tissues and reduces glucose utilization in muscles and fats. It increases gluconeogenesis in the liver, leading to metabolic and hemodynamic disturbances, metabolic syndrome [21], and diabetes [42]. Obesity indices used in this study were simple and clinically useful insulin resistance surrogate markers [21].

BMI, as a common obesity marker, can be used to measure lipid accumulation but might not completely represent abnormal adipose tissue deposition, as it is unable to distinguish muscle mass from fat mass [43]. LAP, TyG, and VAI have been introduced as indicators of ‘visceral adipose function’ and insulin resistance. AIP is the product of TG and HDL-C, and CMI is the product of the waist-to-height ratio and TG/HDL-C. Both can determine cardiometabolic disease risk and T2DM [44, 45]. LAP represents increased lipotoxicity [42] and is a better predictor of metabolic syndrome than BMI or WC, with the highest predictive accuracy [13].

FPG is a confirmatory plasma venous determinant of diabetes and is the mainstream screening index [6]. We used FPG for adjustment in the analysis and significant associations were found for AIP, CMI, LAP, and VAI. Mets-IR and TyG are derived from FPG indices and are integrated indicators of insulin resistance and metabolic dysfunction. This may partially explain the stronger associations for Mets-IR and TyG than for the other index in both sexes in this study. The simplicity of these indices, based on routine clinical tests, makes them promising screening tools for diabetes [6].

Studies in diverse populations with varying genetic backgrounds have observed consistent associations between obesity indices and diabetes risk [6], e.g., in American [21], European [3, 15], and Asian [18, 19, 22, 24–26, 46] populations. The positive associations were also consistent with Japanese studies on LAP [28, 46], CMI [47], Mets-IR [29], TyG [29, 30], and VAI [28]. In our study, TyG and VAI values were similar to those in Thai [14], Chinese [20], and American [21] populations; Mets-IR was lower than in Thai [14] and Indonesian [23] populations; and AIP, LAP, and VAI were higher than in Thai [14], Chinese [17, 20], American [21], and Dutch [40] populations.

For Japanese populations, Wakabayashi et al. reported LAP values of 20.9 for males and 11.4 for females aged 35–40 years [27], and 23.9 overall for those aged 35–60 years [48]. The NAGALA study found LAP at 13.6 for males and 6.65 for females [46], with mean TyG at 7.91 [30]. Our study had higher LAP and VAI values than the NAGALA study [28]. In the above index values, TyG was similar in the Japanese and other populations; however, LAP in our study was higher than that in others, which requires further study. The high LAP level may reflect the high overweight/obesity and lifestyle-related risk among Fukushima residents, who ranked worst in the country [38].

Our findings suggest that novel combined indices were overall stronger risk markers of T2DM, particularly in females [24] and both sexes with a BMI < 25 kg/m2 or aged < 50 years. This may be due to the higher lifestyle-related risk and anthropometric and laboratory measures in males than in females, resulting in higher LAP, TyG, and VAI [40]. A Japanese study observed a J-shaped relationship between alcohol consumption and LAP, which was modified by smoking and exercise; however, alcohol consumption did not change the relationship between LAP and hyperglycemia [48]. In the FDB group, we did not observe a significant association between physical activity, exercise, and T2DM in men and women. The insignificant association of LAP in Q4 vs. Q1 in overweight/obese women might be due to the lower proportion of obesity in women (21.8%). The insignificant nonlinear relationships in LAP in women may support this finding. The TyG index was more likely to be higher in concurrent smokers and alcohol consumers [49]. The complexity and disparity in risk factors between males and females highlight the need for further studies on T2DM risk.

The diagnostic performance of indices in our study, adjusted for covariates including blood plasma glucose, was similar to that of Chinese studies for LAP and VAI [20]. It was higher than other studies for TyG [14, 24], Mets-IR [14], LAP [14, 18], and VAI [14, 18]. Referring to the AIP model with the highest AUC, the same predictive ability was observed for CMI and LAP; however, inferior performance was observed for Mets-IR, TyG, and VAI. This finding indicates that AIP, CMI, and LAP may be prominent predictors of T2DM risk in young and middle-aged Japanese. Although tests of NRI and IDI have been shown to have inflated false-positive rates [50], this study was not designed to develop risk prediction models but rather to assess the discriminant ability of these indices. Nevertheless, although we explored indices’ discriminant ability, given point estimation of cut-off values with confidence intervals, which could be elucidated differently across different study populations [27, 31]. Further evidence, including studies in clinical settings for calibration, is needed, particularly regarding the accuracy and applicability necessary to evaluate if used further for clinical guidance. Recent work using continuous glucose monitoring dynamics has introduced novel markers for detecting diabetes onset and tracking disease progression, complementing traditional obesity-related indices [51]. Additionally, machine learning models have been explored in other diabetes contexts, such as predicting diabetic retinopathy, demonstrating the broader potential of data-driven tools for early risk identification [52].

The strength of this study was that it included a large population with a higher proportion of annual health checkup attendance; thus, the study results may be generalized to other populations. The associations were measured through an identified cohort over more than 4 years of follow-up, showing similar significant results in the sensitivity analysis. Multiple imputations were performed for missing data, showing similar results to the complete case analysis and providing point and sensitive estimates of cut-off values for indices of T2DM risk. Nevertheless, for health promotion purposes, the study findings will be helpful for counseling and early identification of T2DM for clinicians and public health practitioners. Moreover, insurance databases with obesity indices can serve as surveillance tools for monitoring individual lifestyle improvements.

However, this study had limitations. First, is that due to the availability of measurements in health checkups, we could not study and compare indices such as hip index, body adiposity index, and body fat percentage. Second, we only computed the baseline indices and could not clarify whether they affected the associations measured over the years [7, 16]. Third, socioeconomic factors, such as educational level, family history of T2DM [18], family income [1], and occupation [53], which were significant determinants of lifestyle and health literacy in diabetes, were not available for adjustment in the regression analysis [1]. This study may have overestimated the associations between the obesity indices and T2DM risk due to the absence of these covariates. Future studies developing models predicting T2DM risk using these indices may require additional covariates. In addition, LAP calculations were based on examinations in Western countries, which may need to be updated for the Japanese population.

In summary, this study underscores the value of using multiple obesity indices, rather than relying on a single health metric, to predict T2DM incidence risk among young and middle-aged Japanese individuals. This study provides clinically relevant information on the value of obesity indices in predicting T2DM risk in the general population. In particular, referring to the cut-off values of AIP, CMI, and LAP, may assist in estimating T2DM risk. Indices based on routine clinical tests may help in a primary care setting to identify high-risk individuals, for early diagnosis, or for the evaluation of complications in patients with diabetes. However, to validate our findings further, repeated studies for designing, developing, and implementing better diabetes screening tools in standard approaches for the assessment, monitoring, and education in communities or among individuals for prevention of T2DM are needed.

notes.title: Availability of data and materials

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate

The study was conducted using secondary administrative data accumulated in the database, with personal information anonymised. Thus, informed consent was not obtained from participants.
